text: i want to introduce you to the guest
speaker tonight allison king
allison is mba 2008 she was a very
involved
student when she was at hbs and she
continues to be a very involved alum
she's the first one i call when i need
someone on
the panel so thank you alison for that
she's currently the director of global
marketing at genzyme
and i know she hired at least one of you
guys to be a summer intern so you want
to stay in touch with her too
and she the reason she's here is because
she's on the board for prize for life
which she'll talk about more extensively
which is really a groundbreaking
organization
looking at different ways to raise money
and to support als research so without
further ado i'll turn it over to allison
thank you cara for that introduction and
i am gonna i brought my notes up because
i actually did have slides and
unfortunately we're having some
technical difficulty
and so i won't be able to share with you
some of the fun photos to kind of make
my speech a little bit more entertaining
so
apologize for that but i want to just
first start by thanking the organizers
of this event
from the healthcare club and the
healthcare initiative i was extremely
honored to be asked to come back and i
have to say
it gave me a little bit of an ego boost
to be invited to come back to speak at
hbs four years after graduation
and my husband who graduated a year
after me i think he was a little bit
jealous that i got the invitation to
come back before he did so
thanks for giving me a leg up on the
competition at home
so just a little bit about me just to
add to what kara said
i was class of 08 section i
and i was kind of classic career
switcher i came to hbs
after four years at morgan stanley in
investment banking
knowing that i wanted to make a switch
into healthcare
and so i took advantage of everything
that hbs had to offer
including the healthcare initiative
which is a very
near and dear cause to my heart and so
it's great to see that it's expanding in
size every year
and to see so many of you guys here
today it really helped
me find my path into my career
and so i interned at genzyme in the
business development group and then
joined full-time
upon graduation i'm currently in my
third role at genzyme within three and a
half years
and i'll talk about that a little bit
later about rotating around
and as kara said i also sit on the board
of directors of prize for life which i'm
going to talk about today
and in addition to that i'm expecting a
baby girl in september
so i'm very excited
but so i want to talk to you guys today
about how i got into the healthcare
industry
and my path from kind of a banker to
person in healthcare and i hope what you
take away from today with from my
experience
is that pursuing your passion really
does pay
and it may not pay off today or tomorrow
but i guarantee that in
unexpected and potentially unintended
ways it will eventually pay off
and i hope you also leave today with
kind of the importance of giving back to
your community
and i think that we all have a
responsibility to give back to our
community
i'm going to talk about one way today
which that i pursued through prize for
life but
i hope that you all um go back into your
into the real world and give back to our
community
um so i wanted to start by introducing
you um
to avi kramer i would have had a photo
here where i would have showed you him
but many of you may be familiar with his
story he was class of 06
from hbs and i'd like you to think back
to your rc year
not that long ago for most of you but
when you first started here
and all the hopes and expectations you
had and
how exciting it was getting to know your
section anticipating that first cold
call
hanging out with your friends and avi
arrived here from israel
you know his first time living in the
u.s full of all those same hopes and
expectations
and he got here and he noticed that he
was experiencing some muscle cramps in
his hands
and also some muscle weakness but he
tried to ignore it because he was so
busy
going about the usual rc things you know
going to priscilla ball and
taking advantage of everything rcur had
to offer but eventually he couldn't
ignore his symptoms anymore and he was
referred
to a local neurologist here in boston
who eventually referred him to a
specialist
and after many tests and ruling out
pretty much everything else
he was given his worst nightmare which
was
a diagnosis of als and at age 29 he was
told he had three to five years to live
and so you can imagine how devastating
that diagnosis is but
just to put it in context for you and
give you a few facts about als
number one it's an orphan disease which
means
it's rare and it doesn't affect many
people
so the definition of orphan disease in
the u.s is that it flicks
less than two hundred thousand patients
als impacts about thirty thousand
patients at any time one time
and so it is pretty rare and it's
actually quite rare for somebody at
avi's age at age 29 to be diagnosed
it typically impacts people a little bit
later in life in their 40s or 50s
so not only is it rare but it's a
progressive neurodegenerative disorder
that attacks motor neurons so over time
patients lose their ability to walk
talk swallow breathe pretty much
everything and they eventually end up
completely paralyzed at the same time
though their mind remains unaffected
and so they're kind of trapped in their
body
most patients die within three to five
years of respiratory failure
and the cause of the disease is still
unknown about 10
of cases are thought to be genetic but
overall there's little very little known
about the cause of the disease
and unfortunately there are extremely
limited therapeutic options so there's
one drug on the market that's actually
marketed by my parent company sanofi
rulotech which extends life by two
months
so you can imagine that that's not a
great thing to hear from your physician
that we can give you a drug that extends
your life by two months
but that's basically what avi was told
when he was diagnosed he was basically
told
go home prepare your will and get your
affairs in order
and that's the same exact you know
diagnosis that was given to patients
back in the early 1930s when lou gehrig
was diagnosed and he's famously now
the disease is often called lou gehrig's
disease in the u.s and that's also the
same diagnosis
and advice that my father was given when
he was diagnosed
and so you see for me als is actually
quite personal
and i met avi in 06 when i started here
on campus
and this was just a few months after my
father had lost his battle with the
disease
about five percent of patients with als
will live 20 years or longer
and my father happened to be one of
those five percent
and so my father died almost exactly 20
years after he was diagnosed with the
disease
and many patients and families will
often ask me when i meet them like how
did he live for so long
what did he do and i think unfortunately
there's no good scientific or medical
answer
he did what any of us would do he tried
to enroll in every clinical trial
available
he tried you know apheresis and other
crazy
treatments and when nothing works he
resort to whatever will work
i remember once my aunt had somebody
come and meditate in his room all day in
silence you know hoping that that would
cure him
it's that desperate but he tried
everything and i think though at the end
of the day
it was really you know a little bit of
luck but combined with his amazing
spirit to live
and he actually had a motto that he had
taped on in front of his computer
that he looked at every day for the last
10 years of his life which said
als may ultimately kill me but it will
never defeat me
and we really felt like he never was
defeated but when he did lose his battle
with als
i had a realization that my battle
wasn't necessarily over
yet and i felt like i had a
responsibility and i felt like
i had something i could add and so i
wanted to really help patients like my
father
and with other rare diseases and so i
knew i would spend my two years at hbs
kind of figuring out what did that mean
and figuring out what my path was going
to be in life to make this transition
from
investment banker to somebody who's
making an
impact in the healthcare community and
so
now i'll go back to avi's story and i
ask you to put yourself in his shoes
you're three months into hbs and you're
told you have
three to five years to live what would
you do
in his situation and i think that many
of us would consider dropping out of hvs
and going home
spending time with our family and
friends that would be you know one of
the rational things to do
but avi chose to fight which i give him
a lot of credit for
he chose to stay on campus complete his
degree
and he chose to see what he could do to
solve this problem
and he decided to tackle a problem that
obviously researchers have been trying
to solve for over 100 years
but he was audacious enough and bold
enough to think that
he could really make a difference and he
could really make an impact on this
problem
and so he chose to harness kind of the
powerful resources that you have here
available to you at hbs
he got his friends and fellow students
together he got the faculty and
administrators to help him out
and they initially began began
fundraising than that natural thing to
do and they were very successful in
raising
lots of money for als on campus but they
also began to explore
innovative ways in which they could
accelerate als
research and i would say they kind of
approached the problem almost like a
case study
and they looked at for innovative
solutions to an existing problem
and so they went out and talked to
biotech companies like genzyme
and like biogen and asked them why
aren't you investing in als
what would it take for you to enter this
space and develop a therapy
for disease like als they essentially
wanted to help de-risk the investment
and they found that there weren't a lot
of groups out there who were necessarily
focused on
helping bridge that gap that
translational gap between what was
happening in basic
research and at the na nih and in
academia and then what
the for-profit companies were focused on
and so
given the fact that als has two pretty
significant challenges
one that it's neurological and so it's
very complex because it impacts the
brain and central nervous system
and the second being that it's rare and
patients die really quickly
so there's less funding there's less
interest from nih less interest from the
public sector
they wanted to figure out how can we
direct resources to apply
time to this gap and help make it more
attractive to industry to invest
and so avi graduated with his class in
2006 he walked across the stage which
was a momentous occasion
and then shortly around that time he he
founded prize for life
and now he's you know about two years
into his disease and he's decided to
dedicate whatever time he has left
to fighting this disease because he felt
like he really could make an impact
and so they decided to found a prize for
life and the idea was to
use prizes as a powerful incentive to
direct
researchers and money to address that
gap
and so they were inspired to find to do
with the prize model
because of the x prize which some of you
may be familiar with which was a 10
million dollar prize to launch
a commercial aircraft into space and so
they figured this is a good
innovative way that we can tackle this
problem that nobody else is using
and so the first test of the price for
life model was the million dollar
biomarker prize
that they launched in november and 2006
and the idea was that there wasn't a
biomarker for als
which as many of you know is a pretty
critical component if you want to
measure disease progression because
it'll make
clinical trials shorter require less
patience
and essentially cheaper for industry and
so since there wasn't this essential
tool they figured let's see if we can
get people to focus their time and
attention on a biomarker
so they launched a million dollar prize
and the results they saw were pretty
amazing
over a thousand solvers entered the
prize
from 20 different countries so that's a
lot of people suddenly interested in als
two-thirds of the
researchers that who entered into the
prize were from outside
the typical als field and so again it
was attracting new minds to the problem
which is pretty amazing
and then at the end of the day it also
attracted about four million dollars in
investment
to compete for this million dollar prize
and so that was proof that the model
really did work
and we did award a prize last year to dr
seward rutkov who's actually here
at the beth israel and he created a
biomarker
using a technology called eim which
basically looks at electrical currents
and how they travel through muscle
and given that they travel through
healthy muscle and disease muscle
differently you can measure progression
of disease
and so this has the ability to
potentially reduce clinical trial costs
by up to 50 percent and so now this has
really actually gotten the attention of
industry
and so given that the model worked which
was a huge breakthrough
and prize for life are now focused on
aggressively raising money
for our next prizes and also making sure
that we're offering tools to researchers
who are interested in
looking at this translational space so
that they have everything they need to
help
move the research forward and so avi now
is
eight years after his diagnosis and he
is still out there making an impact
even though he runs the organization
from israel he does still travel to the
u.s
and he meets with high net worth donors
he was recently awarded um
a big prize from the prime minister of
israel for the innovative work that he
and prize for life are doing
and so even though he can no longer walk
he can no longer speak very well
and he can no longer gesture and things
like that that are so easy for us
he's still out there every day trying to
make an impact and fighting for all the
patients out there
who have this disease as well and so i
think it's pretty amazing that he's been
able to in this short time
make such an impact on the community
and to just think that it's already been
eight years since his diagnosis he's
already beaten the odds
and so it's really amazing his spirit is
i think is inspirational for everyone
and so i think healthcare is amazing
field to work in because you can make an
impact
i mean everyone in here can be like avi
everyone can make an impact on people
and i think healthcare is an amazing
field to do that and i was drawn to this
industry
because of my own personal like personal
experience
and i really wanted to be part of my
father's legacy and avi's legacy
but i also think you know the healthcare
industry is really appealing because
it's a super dynamic it's a super
challenging industry and i think that
there are always going to be
opportunities in the future
for smart people both in the scientific
and on the business side
and so i think that it's a great place
for hbs mbas to be going into
and i healthcare initiative really
helped me find my path
and i figured it wasn't going to be the
bankers of the world who were solving
these disease problems and so
i was lucky enough to find a place in a
company that i really believe in
and i encourage all of you to just do
the same to find a company you believe
in and then create your own
opportunities
and so i was drawn to genzyme because of
its underlying mission
it basically treats rare diseases so
they look at
very extreme unmet medical needs for
rare diseases
and develop and deliver transformative
therapies and to me i thought if any
company is going to solve als or develop
a treatment for it this is the type of
company that it's going to be
and i really want to be a part of that
and so i joined the company and since
i've been there i've had the opportunity
to work in all different roles
i started in business development given
my finance background from morgan
stanley
i then spent a year and a half working
for the chief operating officer who's
now our ceo
and kind of chief of staff operational
role and then i decided i want to be
closer to our customers and so now in
global marketing i have responsibility
for two of our products for orphan
diseases
and so i really encourage all of you to
carve your own path and go out there
and i think that you'll be able to i'll
be confident that there'll be
opportunities for all of you and so my
personal battle with the disease
continues
there is no cure for als yet there's no
cure for a lot of rare diseases
but i'm confident that there will be a
treatment and most likely in my lifetime
i will see a treatment
and also i feel that my work at price
for life has made me a more valuable
contributor
at genzyme and vice versa i think that
my work at genzyme has made me a more
valuable board member at price for life
and so
i think it's been amazing to kind of
pursue this passion of mine on both my
professional and personal
tracks and so i think as you enter the
healthcare world the real world my
advice would be to you that the
healthcare industry needs all of you
and so there's lots of people out there
there's thousands of people who die from
als each year and there's millions of
people who suffer from diseases
but they don't all have the resources
and skill sets and mindset that avi and
all of you do
and so i encourage you to go out there
and work in the healthcare sector
and as i said too please find a way to
get back to your community i shared my
personal experience today but there's
lots of ways in which you can
give back to your community and i told
you my story today but i know each one
of you has a story and your own reasons
for pursuing this path but make your
story part of your personal brand
and i think it's important to know who
you are what you're passionate about
and what you're good at and follow your
gut and leverage your passion
and i think you have to look at your
career in life as an adventure
and if you do that i think you'll have a
pretty pretty good ride
and obviously i wish all of you guys the
best of luck as you go out into the real
world
i know it's a cliche but these last few
weeks are really special
and i encourage you to enjoy them and i
hope everyone takes some time off
before you go out there and tackle the
real world because it's worth it i
promise
thank you
